learning_outcomes.description: Understand basic concepts, theories, terminologies and history relating to clinical telehealth
Describe types of telehealth and their role in the clinical setting
Understand the role of clinical telehealth in the Australian and global context
Outline the factors for consideration when setting up a facility for clinical telehealth
Describe the factors to consider when conducting clinical telehealth consultations
Discuss the privacy, security and medico-legal issues with clinical telehealth

assessments.task_description:
Assessment Task 1: Perceptions of Telehealth

Detailed instructions and marking criteria will be available to you on the Learn.UQ (Blackboard) Course Assessment page during Teaching Week 2. All tasks associated with this Assessment must be completed by the end of Teaching Week 5. We use the Learn.UQ (Blackboard) for this online activity. During Week 2 you will be randomly assigned to a small group (2 or 3 members). Each group will then be emailed a set of questions and prompts to conduct an interview.

Task 1: Individual interviews on telehealth experience (Individual task - worth 10/30 marks)

• To be conducted prior to Teaching Week 4/Task 2

• You will conduct and take notes of a quick interview with 5 friends or family members (can be from Australia or overseas) who have used telehealth in the past 5 years about their opinion and experience using any modality of telehealth (include mobile health, telehealth consultations using phone or video, teledermatology, teleradiology, etc).

• Questions and prompts will be emailed to you, and the group can choose extra questions they might find useful, if they agree on those before conducting the interviews.

• You will upload your raw data collected from 5 interviews via Learn.UQ (Blackboard) using the template provided.

Task 2: Group analysis, discussion, reflection and summary of findings (Group task - worth 20/30 marks)

• To be conducted during Teaching Weeks 4 and/or 5

• Groups will arrange to meet in person or online to analyse their tabulated responses and discuss the benefits/challenges of using telehealth for clinical practice.

• Specific topic areas to be discussed/template for summarising findings will be provided with the instructions.

• Summary of findings to be uploaded via Learn.UQ (Blackboard)

learning_activities.topic:
Module 1: Clinical telehealth - an overview

Covers Weeks 1 - 3 of teaching.

It offers a comprehensive understanding of telehealth, encompassing the definition of telehealth, tracing its historical origins and evolution into modern healthcare, and examining both initial and recent benefits.

Module 1 introduces you to how telehealth is linked to ensuring fair access to healthcare for patients, aligning with the Australian Charter of Healthcare Rights, addressing the Quadruple Aim of Healthcare, and contribution to the achievement of the United Nations Sustainable Development Goal 3 - Good Health & Well-being.

  • Week 1: What is Telehealth? - What is telehealth and related terms (telemedicine, telecare, e-health and online health), what is clinical telehealth and driver for telehealth  
  • Week 2: Telehealth - the past and the future - History of telehealth and funding related changes since COVID in Australia   
  • Week 3: Benefits of telehealth - Clinical, service and economic benefits of Telehealth, stressing the opportunity to improve access to care      

Refer to the Course 'Learning Resources' on Learn.UQ (Blackboard) for links to all lectures, Weekly Study Guide, required and recommended reading. Content is organised as Module and then by Teaching Week. Content is typically uploaded to Learn.UQ (Blackboard) on the Friday prior to each Teaching Week.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04

learning_activities.topic:
Module 2: Telehealth in action

Teaching Weeks 4-8 explores the different telehealth approaches with respect to delivering healthcare i.e. store and forward models (i.e. asynchronous communication via email, secure messaging, encrypted software,) real-time models (i.e. synchronous communication - video or phone based), mobile-device based models (including remote monitoring/wearables) and hybrid models of care (i.e. a blend of telehealth and face-to-face)

  • Week 4: Approaches to telehealth - an overview - Overview of telehealth briefly explaining all models possible, various classifications and terminologies per specialty
  • Week 5: Telehealth in practice - real-time models - Overview of real-time models, and video and phone consultations
  • Week 6: Telehealth in practice - store and forward models - Overview of store and forward models, teledermatology and eConsults
  • Week 7: Telehealth in practice - mobile health models - Overview of mobile health and potential application for remote patient monitoring
  • Week 8: Telehealth in practice - hybrid models of care - What are models of care, hybrid models, care pathways, the importance of attending to patient needs.

Refer to the Course 'Learning Resources' on Learn.UQ (Blackboard) for links to all lectures, Weekly Study Guide, required and recommended reading. Content is organised as Module and then by Teaching Week. Content is typically uploaded to Learn.UQ (Blackboard) on the Friday prior to each Teaching Week.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06

learning_activities.topic:
Module 3: Planning & implenting telehealth

Teaching Weeks 9-12 outlines practical considerations, technical requirements, planning for a telehealth program and medico-legal considerations. Week 13 is reserved for review of key concepts covered over the Semester that will assist students with final assessment.

  • Week 9: Planning for telehealth - Telehealth Etiquette and Technology for video conferencing
  • Week 10: Privacy considerations and sustainability of telehealth - Privacy & Security in Telehealth, Sustaining telehealth beyond COVID-19
  • Week 11: Telehealth - future potential - Potential of COVIU, telestroke and Tele-ICU
  • Week 12: Telehealth - a global perspective - Telehealth around the world, including case studies from Denmark, Brazil and Japan
  • Week 13: Review

Refer to the Course 'Learning Resources' on Learn.UQ (Blackboard) for links to all lectures, Weekly Study Guide, required and recommended reading. Weeks 9-12 content will be available from Teaching Week 9 to assist students with final assessment preparation.
